Ingredients

  • 200 grams of Potassium Hydroxide flakes (from a DIY shop where they sell soap making kits)
  • 300 grams of Silica Cat Litter, must be pure silica, SiO2!
  • 900 ml water
recipe_potassium.section_2:
Let's cook!



Pour the 900 ml of water into a pot, then add the 200 grams of potassium hydroxide, and finally the 300 grams of cat litter.

It will seem like it will never dissolve, but yes, after about a quarter of an hour of boiling...
recipe_potassium.section_3:

geopolymer_calculator.section_1:
The Kriven Formula

Precise geopolymer formulas are hard to find on the Internet. Not because it is big secret but because the field is still in development (=chaos). One of the leading scientists is Waltraud M. Kriven, we'll use her formula on this page for our calculations. This one:
M•AlO2•2SiO2•5.5H2O
geopolymer_calculator.section_2:
Deciphering the formula

First of all, that capital M at the beginning of the formula is not a chemical element you never heard of but a placeholder for either Sodium (Na) or Potassium (K).

Second, if we omit that bloody oxygen (O) we end up with a much more condensed version:
M•Al•2 Si•5.5 water
geopolymer_calculator.section_3:
In plain English

We want:
  • the same number of "M" (Sodium or Potassium) atoms as Aluminum (Al) atoms in the mix
  • twice as much Silicon (Si) atoms than Aluminum atoms
  • 5.5 times more water molecules than Aluminum atoms

Or in short:

1 part "M", 1 part Aluminum, 2 parts Silicon, 5.5 parts water
geopolymer_calculator.section_4:
Molecular mass and mol

We'll calculate with mols, or 6*1023 atoms (or molecules) at a time. 1 mol material has the convenient property to "calculate" its weight by simply telling "grams" after the molar mass number.

If you are not familiar with these concepts, please learn them before moving on or you'll get lost. Guaranteed.
geopolymer_calculator.section_5:
Example: calculating water's molecular mass

Hydrogen (H) has 1 proton only, so its atomic mass is 1.
Oxygen (O) has 8 protons + 8 neutrons, so it's atomic mass is 16.

What is the molecular mass of water (H2O) then?
1 + 1 + 16 = 18
geopolymer_calculator.section_7:
Locking a parameter: Aluminum

We can easily lock the amount of Al to 1 mol, because we have only one source of Al, the metakaolin. (All the other elements are coming from two sources. Sodium is found both in the waterglass and in NaOH for example.)

1 mol Al2O3 contains 2 mol (or 2 part) Aluminum atoms. But we only need 1 mol Aluminum so we need half mol Al2O3 in our mix to have 1 mol Al. According to our table above, half mol of Al2O3's weight is
102 / 2 = 51 g
geopolymer_calculator.section_8:
How many Metakaolin we need?

We can calculate the whole amount of metakaolin needed by using the percentage ratio of Al2O3 in it. You will find this number in the product data sheet (probably a pdf).

Percentage of Al2O3 in your metakaolin product: %
geopolymer_calculator.section_9:
We have silicon in the metakaolin!

Before we continue: there is another important number in that pdf, that is the percentage of SiO2 in the metakaolin product. This is crucial because it is a constant amount we can only increase but not decrease with the other components. Let's calculate the "hidden" (in plain site) SiO2 content in that  g metakaolin!
geopolymer_calculator.section_10:
Scoreboard

It's time to summarize where we are now. What do we have and what do we miss?
"M" Al Si H2O
Target 1 1 2 5.5
Current 0 1 ✔️ 0
Missing 1 5.5
geopolymer_calculator.section_11:
Mind the gap!

We need to add some other materials to the mix:
geopolymer_calculator.section_12:
Sodium silicate

Now we only need one more (and last) paramterer: the weight percentage of Na2SiO3 in your waterglass solution. It is clearly marked on the bottle, a typical number being 36%.
geopolymer_calculator.section_13:
Follow the yellow brick road, Dorothy!

This is the place where lame gamification kicks in. It was inevitable, sorry. Drag Dorothy left or right on the yellow road to discover the endless variations of valid geopolymer formulas!
geopolymer_calculator.section_14:
Trips and tricks

You can try to find a mix where you don't need to add NaOH or water simply by dragging the slider left or right. Try it!

Or if you don't have waterglass solution on the shelf, you can drag the slider to zero, and end up with a formula without waterglass at all.

Magic!

draft_kaolin.section_1:
The modern geopolymer

Let's review what modern geopolymers, or artificial stones, are made of.
  1. Waterglass - check, the Egyptians knew how to make waterglass.
  2. Metakaolin - a white substance that turns waterglass into stone
draft_kaolin.section_2:
What is metakaolin?

Metakaolin is a silly name for burnt (calcinated) kaolinit. Kaolinit, on the other hand, is a white mineral which is the residue of - wait for it - granite Granite, that has decomposed over millions of years. So, kaolinit is essentially disintegrated ancient granite.

Waterglass needs freely accessible aluminum oxide to turn into stone, which can be found in in kaolinite, and the burning process disintegrates it into white powder.
draft_kaolin.section_3:
Where can we find kaolinite in Egypt?

SURPRISE! Where else (and actually nowhere else), but in Aswan! Where the unfinished obelisk is located. Obviously (?)

We find surface kaolinite fields only a few kilometers from Aswan in the western desert.

It's surely a fatal coincidence that the only place in Egypt where you can find kaolinit is where Egyptians started etching granite to produce waterglass.

draft_dragging.section_1:
Abu Simbel

We have a great example showing how modern man is capable of transporting ancient, multi-ton sandstone colossi carved from a single stone from point A to B.

This occurred during the construction of the Aswan Dam, where several ancient Egyptian temples and giant statues had to be saved from flooding. In 1963, professionals transported two stone temples and these massive, single stone statues to a new place at Abu Simbel.
draft_dragging.section_2:
The technology behind

The technology used was as follows: they lifted the temple and the statues with heavy machinery and helicopters... Oh wait, no.

They actually cut them into 807 pieces. Eight hundred and seven pieces.

Modern man doesn't have any other technology to move these hundred-ton statues other than by cutting them up and moving them piece by piece. This is exactly what happened at Abu Simbel.
draft_dragging.section_3:
How ancient Egyptians did it?

Well, there is a wall painting where we see the Egyptians dragging a huge statue on a wooden sledge across the sand. One person is pouring water in front of the sledge onto the sand to facilitate sliding.

It's certain that this method works. You could drag it all the way to a ship, and you can take the statue as far as you want by boat.
draft_dragging.section_4:
Ancient math lesson

Let's count the number of people pulling the statue. There are 2 x 21 = 42 people standing along each rope, and there are four parallel ropes, making a total of 168 people.

Assuming that one person can drag, say, ~100 kg on the sand, this statue could have been approximately 16.8 tons.

168 person = 16,8 tons.
draft_dragging.section_5:
The Serapeum

In Saqqara, there's a place called the Serapeum, where underground caverns house giant stone sarcophagi, each weighing 40 tons, made from noble stones like granite, basalt, and diorite.

As we just saw, one person can drag ~100 kg. Therefore, to drag such a sarcophagus, 400 (four hundred!) people would be needed. Even if one person could drag ten times more (1 ton), it would still require 40 people. On this narrow space.

If we discard both the UFO and the Harry Potter theories, we don't have many choices left to explain this, but...
draft_dragging.section_6:
Did someone say buckets?

However, there's an additional possibility for how all this could have been done. If the Egyptians knew about artificial stones, they could have brought the raw materials easily into the tunnel in buckets and cast the sarcophagi on site.

So, either they didn't move these 40-ton boxes around at all, or they did it with buckets, depending on your perspective.

domino1_granite.section_1:
Granite, which has a hardness of 7 on the Mohs scale, is so hard that no acid or alkali can harm it. Our ancestors had to use copper chisels and stone tools to carve granite.

WRONG!
Many different chemicals can damage granite, and among them there is also an acid.
domino1_granite.section_2:
Hydrofluoric acid?

Yeah, for the sake of completeness, there is an acid that etches granite. But...

Hydrofluoric acid is nearly impossible to store because it corrodes everything, including glass, ceramics, and metals. Moreover, it is highly toxic. We don't believe our ancestors were handling this acid. They have used something else.
domino1_granite.section_3:
Natron!

However, there is another substance mentioned before, sodium carbonate, or natron in short (Na2CO3), a white powder, which, when heated to 851 degrees Celsius, eats granite for breakfast.

And here, we could recap the list we've already seen of the various uses the Egyptians had for natron. They knew this material very well, not like in our modern times.
domino1_granite.section_4:
How is etching granite possible?

The essence of the matter is that granite is a complex material, with 70-77% of it being SiO2, in different forms like quartz, feldspar and mica. Molten sodium carbonate (natron) breaks down SiO2, and so, granite as well.

This is a piece of red granite after a good bath in molten natron.
domino1_granite.section_5:
What is molten natron?

Molten natron is a liquid. At 851 degrees Celsius, it turns into a glowing, corrosive reddish liquid from its fine white powder form.

Reaching a temperature of 851 degrees Celsius is quite easy with the help of charcoal.

(The natron doesn't etch the stone in this video, but only because the heat dissipates immediately. Don't be impatient.)
domino1_granite.section_6:
A grill chimney!

As you've seen, all you need is a grill chimney and some charcoal to be able to etch granite at home.

Additionally, you'll need some kind of container to put your stone and natron in. This could be an empty tin can.

This setup retains the necessary heat for the natron to stay molten and do its work. And no, this is not how ancient Egyptians did this.
domino1_granite.section_7:
Volcanic rock types

Molten natron also etches all other volcanic rocks with high SiO2 content.

Without claiming to be exhaustive, it also etches these rocks: sandstone, volcanic tuff, diorite, quartzite, basalt.

Which means if you can work on granite with molten natron, you can also work on these stone types as well.

domino2_scoopmarks.section_1:
The Unfinished Obelisk in Assuan, Egypt

The unfinished obelisk is a massive, 40 meters long, 1100-ton granite block, whose carving was inexplicably halted by our ancestors. This has provided a great opportunity for us to examine how they worked.

It's certain that they didn't do it the way a modern person would. There are all sorts of strange processing marks around the obelisk.

And the famous diorite "pounding stones", of course.
domino2_scoopmarks.section_2:
The Scoop Marks Mystery

Around the unfinished obelisk, on the obelisk itself, and next to it in the trench, you can find distinctive depressions known as scoop marks.

According to the official explanation, these were created by diligent individuals using diorite pounding stones to carve them deeper and deeper.
domino2_scoopmarks.section_3:
What's wrong with this explanation?

This explanation has several issues. Not only is it incredibly difficult work, but in some places, like under this another stone (this undercut is NOT below the obelisk), it's downright impossible.

Secondly, it's entirely illogical to create nearly perfectly square depressions when one could make significant progress by simply knocking off the ridges. In fact, crushing the ridges would be "the" solution for this hard carving problem.
domino2_scoopmarks.section_4:
The Natron Theory

The natron theory states that our ancestors weren't foolish.

They didn't start carving granite with pounding stones if they knew that using molten natron made the work much easier. Once they had worked the surface with natron, carving became child's play.

The challenge in heating the granite surface is that the heat dissipates. How did the Egyptians solve this problem?

Tomb of Rekhmire

There's a certain wall painting in the Metropolitan Museum, known as the Tomb of Rekhmire, that depicts metal smelting.

But if you spend some time analysing the picture, you realize this is the most idiotic way of doing any metal work.

Let's see what these guys are actually doing.

Melting iron on the floor?

Let's start with the upper left part. Here, two people are clearly sharpening fire with some tool - on the floor.

The problem with this is that the floor, like any large stone surface, almost sucks the heat out from underneath the tool. Not to mention that what lurks beneath the embers doesn't even look like metal or ore.

Foot bellows

Producing waterglass

domino3_waterglass.section_1:
What is waterglass?

This substance is again a white powder, with the chemical formula Na2SiO3, and it's produced when natron (Na2CO3) breaks down the quartz (SiO2) in the given material.

It extracts the silicon from the stone and assimilates it. It eats quartz for breakfast, while it belches out CO2.

Na2CO3 + SiO2 = Na2SiO3 + CO2
domino3_waterglass.section_2:
What are the properties of waterglass?

Dry waterglass slowly dissolves in water, where it breaks down into sodium ions and silicate ions. In this form, it serves as an excellent paper adhesive.

But if it encounters metal oxides, it shows its real strength: it stimulates them to form various metal silicates, precursors of stones. If you drop different materials into waterglass solution, you'll get this colorful underwater(glass) forest.

Did someone say stone?
domino3_waterglass.section_3:
Geopolymers

If we look more closely at what else waterglass is good for, we quickly realize its real potential.

We have only known since the 1970s that waterglass can be used to create a substance similar to, but harder than concrete, and that doesn't require cement. Moreover, this material can be successfully used in 3D printers, allowing us to "print" houses with it.

The collective name for these materials is geopolymer.
domino3_waterglass.section_4:
Ancient geopolymers?

If we look at ancient stone structures, we can find a million examples where our ancestors somehow softened the stones and worked with them like children playing with clay.

They bent the stones, pressed their hands into them, carved them with knives, or even molded a clumsy little monkey onto them.

In the bottom right corner, it's evident that someone carved out the puma. But the little monkeys look like they are from a different material.
domino3_waterglass.section_5:
Artificial stone

And what a surprise! This is exactly how you can work with waterglass-based artificial stones, the geopolymers. After mixing, they are just like play-doh. An hour later, they start to harden but can still be cut with a knife. After a day, they become as hard as rock.

But why is it black? Waterglass is transparent, right?
domino3_waterglass.section_6:
How to make a stone?

Let's be lazy and try to add the material that's already piling up as waste, since we've melted the stone with fire: wood ash*.

Let's add some water. You get the play-doh above. And after 24 hours you'll have an artificial stone. Or your own Excalibur. BINGO!

*Not just any wood ash. Pine wood ash is the best containing high amount of aluminum oxide.
domino3_waterglass.section_7:
Any proof of ancient waterglass use?

Returning to the original mural, we can see a white pile of something accumulating in the background. That something is contaminated with black specks.

Of course, it's contaminated because it's mixed with the remaining charcoal. Then this white substance is carried around in bags, poured out, and someone molds a wall out of it.

All this is depicted in a singe mural (of smelting metal)!

domino4_fakegranite.section_1:
Artificial stone v1.0

In the previous step, we created truly beautiful artificial stones using nothing but ancient materials — just waterglass and wood ash.

Yes, but the catch is that all these stones are grey, if not outright black.

True, wood ash is almost always gray, and it turns the stone gray (or even black) as well.
domino4_fakegranite.section_2:
We need a transparent binder

But ancient Egyptian stone objects come in every possible color. You can clearly see the grains of the rock. So we’ll need some kind of transparent additive, not wood ash.

And the ingredient can’t be white either, because that would tint the stone white. The grains have to remain visible.

What could it be?
domino4_fakegranite.section_3:
Acids?

Waterglass is alkaline. If you add any kind of acid to waterglass, it precipitates silica gel — a completely transparent glue that hardens into stone when exposed to air. It could be an ideal binder for creating artificial stone.

At least in theory. But no matter what acid I tried—hydrochloric acid, orange juice, vinegar, etc.—the resulting stone didn’t resemble any natural stone. Do you see this example? It’s like it’s made of jelly.

It is beautiful though, and the Nespresso capsule pressed into it gives it an extra charm. But still...
domino4_fakegranite.section_4:
Alcohol?

Alcohols also immediately precipitate the silica gel from waterglass, and for a long time I thought alcohol would be the ultimate solution—after all, it’s good for hangovers, so why wouldn’t it work here?

In the video, we can see how the silica gel instantly separates from the waterglass when an alcoholic drink is added. However, even the alcoholic gel didn’t produce a stone that resembled a natural one.

Okay, what else?
domino4_fakegranite.section_5:
A base?

But we’ve already crossed bases off the list, since bases don’t destabilize waterglass. I won’t beat around the bush—even though it took me two years—the secret additive is a base.

Specifically, slaked lime, but in a very small, 2% dosage, added as a catalyst only. See, it’s alkaline, so in theory it shouldn’t work at all, and it’s white, so it’s not transparent—but by the time the material sets, it becomes clear.
domino4_fakegranite.section_6:
Artificial fake granite

And this is what the final result looks like. This beautiful cast stone isn’t even made from granite rubble, but from plain quartz sand. The ultimate appearance, of course, depends on the type of ground stone—if it’s lemon yellow or mottled, the stone will look the same.

The binder is transparent. Oh, and it’s hard—Mohs 6–6.5. Oh, and it has the same chemical composition as quartz: SiO₂.
domino4_fakegranite.section_7:
But where did the crushed granite come from?

The usual naysayer complaint is always, ‘How did the Egyptians produce all that crushed granite?’ I’ll tell you. They didn’t. Around Aswan, on the east bank of the Nile, there’s a stone desert.

More precisely: a desert of granite rubble. Yeah. Where even the sand is not sand but crushed granite. Yeah. The pink area is. All you need is a shovel and a broom...
domino4_fakegranite.section_8:
And the slaked lime?

Slaked lime is so old-school, it’s been passed around longer than the village gossip. Even cavemen were already using it. Or Adam himself, probably.

How do we know? Easy, anyone wrapping themselves in animal hides is rocking tanned leather, and step one of tanning is soaking the skin in lime putty. So yeah, if you wanted some, you had to pop next door and borrow a cup from the neighborhood tanner.

domino5_nubs.section_1:
What are megalithic nubs?

There is a globally observable phenomenon in megalithic architecture: the nubs—those protruding elements on huge stone blocks, like the ones in Ollantaytambo, Peru.

It takes a truly heroic effort to chisel off an inch of material from the entire surface of such a massive stone to create this protrusion. Or... maybe that's not how they were made?
domino5_nubs.section_2:
Cast or carved?

Now take a look at this roman wall. If these nubs were carved, then the overflow of material on the top of the stones, beyond the mold would also have been carved. Sounds believable, right?

Not at all. Just as no one would be foolish enough to carve nubs, no one would be foolish enough to carve overflow either.
domino5_nubs.section_3:
Bottom, bottom, bottom

Another common characteristic of nubs is that they're found at the bottom of the stones. And when they're not at the bottom, it means the stone has been rotated. Or, if that's not the case, then that nub isn't a nub after all.

Okay, then what else?
domino5_nubs.section_4:
A door hinge?

It's important to note that not all protrusions are "nubs" in the sense we use the term. Real nubs lost their functions long time ago. The reason we don't know their purpose is because they no longer serve one.

But this one, and many others were created with a specific purpose in mind. Artificial stone can intentionally be shaped into forms, such as supports designed to hold up a beam or a door or some another function.
domino5_nubs.section_5:
Rotated stones

This is a clear example of a nub that isn't at the bottom of the stone—but it was during casting. Notice how these stones are uniform in size. This is a sure sign they were cast in molds. And at the bottom of the mold, right in the center, there was a hole.

But why?
domino5_nubs.section_6:
The role of water

To understand the true role of the nubs, we need to explore a characteristic of modern-day concrete. The concrete we use today is a hydrate.

This means that water is an integral part of the concrete. It doesn't harm it; it helps it. Over time, the concrete becomes harder and harder thanks to the water within it.
domino5_nubs.section_7:
Ancient artificial stones

…and this is the polar opposite of how some ancient artificial stones set. While water is also needed for mixing in their case, it becomes entirely unnecessary during the curing process—so much so that if it's not removed, it can ruin the stone.

In fact, water gets released during the curing process right back into the mix and quite literally turns the stone into a puddle if it's not removed.
domino5_nubs.section_8:
1. The first mold has a hole (nub) at the bottom, allowing the water released during the curing process to escape. This mixture feels solid to the touch and remains so as it sets.

2. The second mold (upside down silicone pyramid mold) has no hole at the bottom, but the top is open enough to allow for evaporation. Even so, the material begins to soften during curing.

3. The third mold (plastic food container) was completely sealed, leaving no way for the water to escape. That stone is ruined—it turns into a puddle. Water is running off the top.
domino5_nubs.section_9:
The pudding syndrome

So, unlike concrete, ancient artificial stones can't be built upon at all until the excess water is drained from them. Without nubs, construction comes to a halt.

You can't build a castle on pudding.
domino5_nubs.section_10:
Mitigating the excess water problem

The simplest solution for removing the excess water is a drainage hole. It doesn't matter what the formwork is made of—it could be wood or fabric—a hole needs to be drilled at the bottom.

To prevent the entire stone from leaking out through the hole, a piece of fabric is placed over it, allowing only the water to pass through. The fabric bulges out, but behind it, the nub's material is the same as the stone, which is why it literally hardens into solid rock.

case_splittrap.section_1:
The Mission

In July 2025, armed with an XRF device, I traveled to Croatia to find out whether the limestone blocks with nubs contain any foreign material — in other words, whether they’re natural or man-made.

case_splittrap.section_2:
Ancient Croatia

Croatia is full of megalithic relics, though most of them date back to the Roman era. There are about a dozen abandoned towns like this one scattered along the ridgeline of the Dinaric Alps.

I visited five or six of these sites and eagerly pressed the XRF device’s lens against the walls, but it didn’t detect any foreign material. Instead, I found something else: mortar between the stones. And where there’s mortar, it’s not true polygonal masonry, so it’s no surprise there was no potassium.
case_splittrap.section_3:
Brač

Searching for ancient sites led me to this limestone cave on the island of Brač. It’s called Dragon’s Cave, and I wouldn’t recommend anyone attempt the hike without the official guide — the scorching heat is one thing, but at the end of the trail the cave will be locked. The guide is the one with the key.

Well, guess what — was there any potassium in this rock? You win! There wasn’t!
case_splittrap.section_4:
Diocletian Palace in Split

My final destination was the city of Split, where the beautifully restored 2nd-century Diocletian’s Palace is the pride of the city.

And sure enough, we find limestone blocks with nubs all over the place — sometimes in truly impossible locations, but that doesn’t deter a real researcher from scientific investigation.

Out with the XRF device! No potassium. What the heck?
case_splittrap.section_5:
In the basement

I had almost given up hope; I thought either the tool went wrong or I fundamentally didn’t understand how the device worked. Back then I didn’t yet know that this instrument only ‘sees’ a few micrometers deep — a depth from which potassium could easily have been washed away by thousands of years of rain.

In hindsight, I now realize I should have looked for a stone in a protected location from the start, say one that’s down in the basement of Diocletian’s Palace.
case_splittrap.section_6:
Bingo!

A stone exactly like this one here. I’ll show you the way if you ever feel like making a pilgrimage to it. It’s not far: down in the basement, first room on the right, then straight across, and voilà.

Sure, it’s cracked all over the place—which is already weird for a lintel stone—but the important thing now is: it DOES have potassium in it! Bingo!
case_splittrap.section_7:
The potassium content

Why do I think the potassium content means the stone is artificial? Because in marine sedimentary limestone—like the kind the Dinaric Alps are made of—there is definitely no potassium.

And the reason is that potassium compounds are highly soluble in water and simply get flushed away with the displaced seawater. The only natural limestones that can contain potassium are those where the water gets trapped and evaporates, leaving it behind.

Pamukkale limestone, for instance, contains potassium. It is a fresh, freshwater limestone formed by evaporation.
case_splittrap.section_8:
Mud cracks

So, where’s the catch? Pay attention: these aren’t just ordinary cracks. They didn’t come from weight—there’s nothing above, only a cavity—but from drying! That’s right: so called mud cracks!

But how could that happen? Does natural limestone swell underwater and then crack when it dries?

Absolutely not. Natural limestone can’t do that. Only some soggy sludge behaves this way.
case_splittrap.section_9:
Our ancestors were idiots?!

If the cracks couldn’t have appeared afterward, what if they were there from the start?

That would mean the ancient stonemasons were bloody idiots.

But seriously—what are the chances that the stonemasons back then would pick the absolute worst, all-shattered stone for a lintel? A LINTEL ffs!
case_splittrap.section_10:
Catch-22

So the cracks couldn’t have formed afterward, because natural limestone doesn’t do that—and artificial limestone didn’t exist.

And it couldn’t have formed beforehand either, because then they wouldn’t have chosen it as a lintel.

We’ve reached a crossroads: this lintel is either made of artificial limestone—or the people who installed it were complete idiots, putting a cracked stone in as a lintel. Q. E. D.

carvings.section_1:
Petra, Jordan

The huge ancient stone carvings have always amazed modern people. How did they do it? With copper chisels? That's impressive! A superhuman feat! But what if our ancestors weren't that crazy and instead chose an easier method?

Let's assume they were aware of the stone-etching function of molten natron. However, for "carvings" of such magnitude, they would have almost needed an unlimited supply of natron.

Let's see, how far is the nearest unlimited natron deposit from Petra!
carvings.section_2:
What is that white patch?

Approximately 20 kilometers east of Petra lies a vast white expanse in the desert, spanning several kilometers in diameter. What could this be?

It seems improbable that it's snow since this is not a high mountain region but one of the lowest areas on Earth. Limestone? No. Limestone typically forms mountains, not a spread scattered across the desert's surface.

That leaves us with salt. But what kind of salt?
carvings.section_3:
Salts are different

There are various types of salts, with table salt (NaCl) being just one of them. Their common characteristics include the ability to dissolve in water and precipitate when the water evaporates.

Besides table salt (NaCl), there's Epsom salt (MgSO4), road salt (MgCl2), and of course washing soda or natron (Na2CO3), just to name a few.

How do we produce them? (And why is it important?)
carvings.section_4:
Salt evaporation

For millennia, humanity has been producing the different kind of salts it needs through salt evaporation ponds. The principle here is that while the water evaporates and the pond slowly dries up, the salt remains at the bottom of the pond and crystallizes.

Why is this important to us? Because exactly the same thing happens in nature, with just a tiny twist. Those salt evaporation ponds aren't different colors by chance, but because...
carvings.section_5:
Precipitation order

Salts don't all precipitate at the same time. Some salts remain in the diminishing water much longer, while others precipitate in a rush. Salts have a precipitation order, with natron leading the way.

As a salty lake dries up and gradually recedes, it deposits the salts it contains onto its shores in the sequence of precipitation of salts. There will be a band of natron,followed by a band of such salts, then another type of salt, and finally, table salt remains at the very end. Here is a typical precipitation order:
  1. Natron (Sodium carbonate)
  2. Calcium sulfate
  3. Magnesium sulfate
  4. Potassium chloride
  5. Sodium chloride (Table salt)
carvings.section_6:
Naqsh e Rostam, Iran

Let's start with a place we'll probably never visit in person, because we wouldn't want to lose half an arm over a pair of shorts or a glass of beer. We're traveling to Iran, to a site called Naqsh-e Rostam. Officially, it's a burial place.

Officially, of course, every site of unknown purpose is considered a burial site, and this one was also carved out with sticks, obviously.

Ok, so where is the salt?
carvings.section_7:
Where is the salt?

For this location, the nearest salt lake is so ridiculously close that I don't even need to measure it on the map. Practically two steps away is Tashk Lake, and it screams salt lake from the map, with the white deposits visible around the shoreline on the satellite image.

The salt deposits stretch almost all the way to the monument. This is almost like cheating. What a coincidence!

The next one won't be that easy I promis.
carvings.section_8:
Derinkuyu, Turkey

In Turkey's Cappadocia, there are hundreds of underground cities carved into the rock, among which Derinkuyu is the largest. With its 18 levels of depth and capacity to house 20,000 people, it astonishes people today.

It's true that these cities are carved into volcanic tuff, which is a relatively "soft" stone, but even so, excavating such a large quantity with primitive tools must not have been easy.

Ok, so where is the salt?
carvings.section_9:
Where is the salt?

About 30 kilometers east of Derinkuyu, there is a vast saltwater lake called Yay Gölü, where salt extraction continues to this day with absolutely primitive methods. (Collecting it from the ground.)

BTW: why didn't they start carving the rock right at the lakeshore? Well, because there's usually no volcanic rock at the shores of carbonated lakes. This is a limestone area. We need to move from carbonate-rich soils to volcanic soils to find quartz to work with.
carvings.section_10:
Cappadocian truth

The reality is even more intriguing. Take a look at the attached map of Cappadocia. The blue markers indicate salt lakes, while the yellow ones represent underground cities.

Those hundreds of underground cities are located at the epicenter of a quadrangle inhabited by four large salt lakes. This geographical setup adds an extra layer of fascination to the region's rich history and unique underground constructions.
carvings.section_11:
The Late Buddha of Bamiyan, Afganisthan

What happened to the Buddha of Bamiyan is indeed outrageous. In 2001, the Taliban, citing various religious pretexts, destroyed the Buddha statue, which held a prominent place on the World Heritage list.

Worshipping idols is a sin against God. And what about the destruction of ancient cultural monuments?

Draw a veil over it, where is the salt?

carvings.section_13:
Salinization

Now you can also figure out that if that spot there next to Petra is salt, then due to the precipitation sequence, it's almost certainly natron. The same thing happens everywhere in the world, where either the water or the soil is salty.

And it's important to note that it's enough for the soil to be salty. The lake may be freshwater, but ground water will eventually pump up sodium to the surface. This latter process is called salinization, and it will be important later on.
carvings.section_14:
Any proof of ancient waterglass use?

Returning to the original mural, we can see a white pile of something accumulating in the background. That something is contaminated with black specks.

Of course, it's contaminated because it's mixed with the remaining charcoal. Then this white substance is carried around in bags, poured out, and someone molds a wall out of it.

All this is depicted in a singe mural (of smelting metal)!
